oai_dc:dc.dc:title: CALIBRATION OF SHORELINE PREDICTION MODEL USING ENSEMBLE KALMAN FILTER
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chen, Xinyu
Shimura, Tomoya
Miyashita, Takuya
Banno, Masayuki
Mori, Nobuhito
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The increasing greenhouse gas emissions induce global warming, leading to sea-level rise (SLR). In particular, climate change has already been becoming apparent in the coastal environment. The most significant variation due to SLR is shoreline change. A proper model that could predict the shoreline change on a large scale and a long-term is urgently needed. Models in different aggregation levels have been developed to study shoreline morphology in various spatial and temporal scales (e.g., Yates et al., 2011; Splinter et al., 2014). This study aims to discover the drivers of shoreline behavior and especially understand the wave climateâ€™s impact on shoreline to reduce the uncertainty of shoreline in the long-term forecast.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; sediment.16
